Issues.Title: Could I build a component in the structure (in chinese is  总-分 结构) just put structure above and the following is details?
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/67459619/why-the-v-slot-did-not-work-in-a-single-file/67461263#67461263
I am a new vue user and i dont know how to achive the goal:
Just build a component like using this structure but actually not use slot (slot will return errors.)
```
<v-row>
  <v-col cols="6"> this is first box: <slot name="first" /></v-col>
  <v-col cols="6"> this is second box: <slot name="second" /></v-col>
  <template v-slot:first> something first.... </template>
  <template v-slot:second> something second.... </template>
</v-row>
```

### What does the proposed API look like?
To make this work and maybe not use slot actually.
```
<v-row>
  <v-col cols="6"> this is first box: <slot name="first" /></v-col>
  <v-col cols="6"> this is second box: <slot name="second" /></v-col>
  <template v-slot:first> something first.... </template>
  <template v-slot:second> something second.... </template>
</v-row>
```

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Value of input resets on blur if value of another variable is rendered
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://codepen.io/raza-farooq/pen/KKWwGep](https://codepen.io/raza-farooq/pen/KKWwGep)







### Steps to reproduce
1) On the view, type in `222` after `Hello` and click somewhere outside of input. You will see that `222` disappears and it reverts back to `Hello`.

2) Remove `{{ test }}` from the code and do the test again. You will see that the input value is still `Hello222`.


### What is expected?
Both cases should have the same value, which is `Hello222`.

### What is actually happening?
Two different values are being produced, simply because I'm displaying the value of `test`.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Is there any API to unreactive proxy instance to original object
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
I'm a Firefox add-on developer.
It's not supported to save the reactive form data into chrome.storage.local, which is one kind of local storage provided by Firefox for add-ons.
So I want unreactive the form data before saving, and I don't find any API in reactivity.d.ts

### What does the proposed API look like?
``` javascript
const proxy = new Proxy({name:'123', no:'321'})
const data = unreactive(proxy)
```

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Is there any API to unreactive proxy instance to original object" (#12057)

Issues.Title: webpack v5 and vue 3.0.11
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.11

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/evenstensberg/vue-react-module-federation/tree/master/lib/vue](https://github.com/evenstensberg/vue-react-module-federation/tree/master/lib/vue)







### Steps to reproduce
1. Clone the repository
2. Run npm install
3. Run npm run dev

### What is expected?
Sucessfully compiled build

### What is actually happening?
Errors in console

---
Hey! It would be awesome if you had webpack 5 compatibility with vue 3, even though vue 3 mainly is invoked through the vue cli. This would enable developers to try out new features such as Module Federation. Building a webpack project from scratch is very hard, but for some developers, this is the way to go to get a full overview of what is happening. Vue-tempate-compiler needs to be updated to vue 3, since one of the errors complains about that. Is there any way for me to help from a webpack stance of this? If so, please feel free to reach out! Thanks! Even

It might be a Chrome related problem, a kind of "Lock", "Unlock" with a click history state situation ?

Issues.Title: Example server configurations only work for single page apps
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.5.1

### Reproduction link
[https://router.vuejs.org/guide/essentials/history-mode.html#example-server-configurations](https://router.vuejs.org/guide/essentials/history-mode.html#example-server-configurations)

### Steps to reproduce
The [example server configurations](https://router.vuejs.org/guide/essentials/history-mode.html#example-server-configurations) in the Vue Router documentation only work for single page apps, not [multipage apps](https://cli.vuejs.org/guide/html-and-static-assets.html#building-a-multi-page-app).

### What is expected?
The server should return the correct html content for the specific page requested from a multipage app.

### What is actually happening?
The server returns unexpected and incorrect content when the user tries to navigate to other pages in a multipage app.

---
I recommend adding a note to the documentation warning that multipage apps may require more sophisticated server configuration. An example would be helpful, but not necessary.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Example server configurations only work for single page apps" (#3537)

Issues.Title: Please explain the effect of using dynamic components in <router-view>
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
It is given in the official document (https://next.router.vuejs.org/zh/api/#router-view-的-v-slot):

```
<router-view v-slot="{ Component, route }">
  <component :is="Component" />
</router-view>
```

Use the dynamic component example like this. At the same time, this form is also common in other Vue projects. But why use it like this? The benefits and side effects are not clearly stated. Hope the document can supplement this content.

### What does the proposed API look like?
supplement explanation in https://next.router.vuejs.org/zh/api/#router-view-的-v-slot

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: A route component should unmount before navigation happens
Issues.Body:
### Version
4.0.6

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/awesome-albattani-b1uvt](https://codesandbox.io/s/awesome-albattani-b1uvt)







### Steps to reproduce
In the linked CodeSandbox open the console and follow these steps:

1. Click on `Route 2` link
2. Click on `Home` link
3. Check URL bar and console output

### What is expected?
After navigation from `/route` to `/` I should see the correct URL in the URL bar -> `/` and the console output should be:

Route.vue unmount 
Navigated to:  / 
HelloWorld.vue mounted 

### What is actually happening?
After navigation from `/route` to `/`, the URL bar shows `/?test=hello` and the console output is:

Navigated to:  / 
Route.vue watchEffect:  / 
Route.vue unmount 
HelloWorld.vue mounted 

---

By having a `watchEffect` that depends on the `route` value this bug causes code to run after a route change happened and can trigger unintended side effects.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "A route component should unmount before navigation happens" (#3538)

I recommend adding a note to the documentation that multipage apps may require more sophisticated web server configuration.

Issues.Title: router link class change on click ignored after the first time
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.5.1

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/vue-routing-example-forked-2ggs5?file=/views/Home.vue](https://codesandbox.io/s/vue-routing-example-forked-2ggs5?file=/views/Home.vue)


### Steps to reproduce
Step 1: 
Click on any category link. The background turn to pink and the text grows. After 2 seconds the transition finishes, the user is redirected to the next page. 

Step 2:
Click on Home, and than click on any category link.

### What is expected?
The css class name should turn to `active` for the clicked link at step 2 the same way as it happens at step 1

### What is actually happening?
At step 2 the css class is not set. The background color and the text size does not change.

---
The `active` variable is set on click, but it seems the `:class` binding does not get it only for the very first time. Tested on Arch Linux with Chromium 90.0.4430.85 and Firefox Developer Edition 89.0b4

I have animations what should run when the user clicks a link for the link they clicked on.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "router link class change on click ignored after the first time" (#3534)

Issues.Title: mode "abstract" and router onReady
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.5.1

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/brave-agnesi-lv8dy?file=/__tests__/router.spec.js](https://codesandbox.io/s/brave-agnesi-lv8dy?file=/__tests__/router.spec.js)







### Steps to reproduce
while in abstract mode, simply add any functionalities inside the router.onReady method and watch tests failing when trying to expect code inside of it to be called.

### What is expected?
code written inside the `onReady` method should be called in abstract mode just like in history or hash mode


### What is actually happening?
nothing inside `onReady` is called when in abstract mode

---
the abstract mode seems to be the preferred method to be used when performing testing with vue-router because is the only one that it's cleared on each iteration, but then it doesn't give the same results as the other modes.

as shown in the simple tests I wrote in codesandbox, the console.log is not called in abstract mode

Issues.Body:
### Version

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/stickeegreg/vue-router](https://github.com/stickeegreg/vue-router)

### Steps to reproduce
Use a bundled (webpack) copy of Vue, but also have a non-bundled version (window.Vue)

Clicking a router link will give errors such as `[Vue warn]: $attrs is readonly.`

### What is expected?
Vue-router should use the bundled Vue instance, when `Vue.use(VueRouter)` is called.

### What is actually happening?
Vue-router is [automatically registering itself](https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/blob/670e5c09918169bded57b84f1aa238e895a27e2e/src/index.js#L290) using `window.Vue.use(VueRouter)` before `Vue.use(VueRouter)` is called

---
Apologies for not including a reproduce case before - I had submitted it as a feature request so the form didn't ask me for one.

I realise this is an unusual use-case, and your initial reaction is likely to be "just don't use 2 copies of Vue" but what I'm doing is valid and is something other libraries support (e.g. jQuery's noConflict mode). I'm creating a web component that others will be able to embed in their own websites, therefore I have no control over whether there will be a global version of Vue loaded or not. I need to use the bundled one, because even if there is a global one, it may not be the correct version.

My initial idea would be to create a no-conflict.js and then change index.js to export everything from no-conflict and do the auto-registration.

I can create a PR if you'd like but maybe there's a better way to do it?

Issues.Title: state 'hasOwnProperty' getter reactivity
Issues.Body:
### Version
4.0.0

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/vue-3-vuex-4-test-forked-926e7?file=/src/store/index.js](https://codesandbox.io/s/vue-3-vuex-4-test-forked-926e7?file=/src/store/index.js)







### Steps to reproduce
The minimal reproduction starts with an empty state, then fetches data from an api (with a delay). To reproduce, just run the app with the `if` test using `hasOwnProperty`.

### What is expected?
The computed property should react to the state update whe the API returns.

### What is actually happening?
When `hasOwnProperty` is used, the computed property never reacts when the state updates. However when `in` is used it works as expected.

---
`hasOwnProperty` was working on Vue2/Vuex3, but no longer works on Vue3/Vuex4. I'm happy to be told that `hasOwnProperty` is the 'wrong way' to check `state` but given it's a commonly used method on objects I thought it worth flagging up this unusual behaviour.

Issues.Title: build(deps): bump handlebars from 4.7.6 to 4.7.7
Issues.Body:
Bumps [handlebars](https://github.com/wycats/handlebars.js) from 4.7.6 to 4.7.7.
Changelog

Sourced from handlebars's changelog.

v4.7.7 - February 15th, 2021

  • fix weird error in integration tests - eb860c0
  • fix: check prototype property access in strict-mode (#1736) - b6d3de7
  • fix: escape property names in compat mode (#1736) - f058970
  • refactor: In spec tests, use expectTemplate over equals and shouldThrow (#1683) - 77825f8
  • chore: start testing on Node.js 12 and 13 - 3789a30

(POSSIBLY) BREAKING CHANGES:

  • the changes from version 4.6.0 now also apply in when using the compile-option "strict: true". Access to prototype properties is forbidden completely by default, specific properties or methods can be allowed via runtime-options. See #1633 for details. If you are using Handlebars as documented, you should not be accessing prototype properties from your template anyway, so the changes should not be a problem for you. Only the use of undocumented features can break your build.

That is why we only bump the patch version despite mentioning breaking changes.

Issues.Title: Plugin subscribe to state change only (not just any mutation)
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
It seems like the subscribe callback occurs even if a mutation doesn't actually change the state.  For persisting a large vuex store in a plugin, this seems be super inefficient.

### What does the proposed API look like?
subscribeChange(state) 

Would only be called when the state has changed.

Issues.Title: Can't use `this`  with helpers function
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.6.2

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/aged-feather-stzbi?file=/src/App.vue](https://codesandbox.io/s/aged-feather-stzbi?file=/src/App.vue)


### Steps to reproduce
Use `this` inside of parameters in vuex helpers 

```
computed: {
    ...mapGetters('page/'  +  this.$route.params.id, ['foo']),
 }
``` 

### What is expected?
The map getters to map to the submodule "page/{id}"

### What is actually happening?
This throw en error :

> Cannot read property '$route' of undefined

### Some context

I am using <keep-alive/> to store multiple "pages" in instance. Each page is triggered by the router. So when the route change, current page goes to sleep, and the one with the proper id goes awake.
Each page registers its own vuex "page" module.

Today I am doing
```
// page.vue

computed: {
  foo() {
      return this.$store.state.page[this.$router.route.params.id].foo
    },
}
```
But it's verbose. And I don't need to react on `this.$router.route.params.id` as each page has its own module.

Issues.Title: Return the original promise instead of throwing an error and returning a new rejected promise
Issues.Body:
Fixes #1969 - refer to this issue for background and demo.

This change only affects the developer experience, and only when using the Vue devtools extension (as far as I can tell; it relates to code that is only called when `store._devtoolHook` is defined).

The code in question deals with catching rejected promises in actions, so that the devtools hook can be notified by emitting an event. The original code was also returning the new caught promise, which meant that it then also needed to re-reject the promise so that the app code can carry on unaffected (as if the promise had never been caught in the first place. This was done by throwing the promise rejection reason as an error. This has a side effect of causing the browser's own devtools to pause when using the "pause on exceptions" feature, because from the browser's perspective this is an uncaught exception - an error has been thrown, and the browser is not concerned about whether this is happening in a promise, or whether the promise rejection is subsequently handled safely. Since there's no "real" error here, this behaviour can be annoying during development when testing code that should be resilient to promise rejections.

However, the need to throw an error can be avoided entirely if the caught promise is not what gets returned by the action - the promise can be caught for the purpose of notifying the devtools hook, while still returning the original un-caught promise.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Return the original promise instead of throwing an error and returning a new rejected promise" (#1970)

Issues.Title: Return a rejected promise rather than use `throw` in actions when registering the devtools hook
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.6.2

### Reproduction link
[https://x422e.csb.app/](https://x422e.csb.app/)







### Steps to reproduce
This issue only occurs when using the Vue devtools extension (as far as I can tell) - however note that the issue is within Vuex and not the devtools extension. The issue occurs when `store._devtoolHook` is defined in the Vuex source.

- Configure the browser's devtools debugger to break on exceptions (but not on caught exceptions) - e.g. in Firefox devtools go to the Debugger tab, expand the Breakpoints pane, and tick "Pause on exceptions"
- Open the CodeSandbox demo with devtools open, and the Vue devtools extension installed
- Observe that the devtools debugger will pause on a line of Vuex `throw err;`


### What is expected?
The devtools debugger should not pause, because no error was thrown in the app code. A promise was rejected, but it was also caught and handled properly, so there's no error.

### What is actually happening?
This error is being thrown as part of Vuex's function to register an action, where promise rejections are caught and emitted for the devtools hook, and then the promise rejection reason is thrown in order to re-reject the promise so that the app code is unaware that Vuex had handled the rejection at all.

However, throwing an error also triggers the browser's "pause on exceptions" handler, even though this particular code is not technically "erroring".

A safer way to handle re-rejecting the promise is to simply return a rejected promise instance using `return Promise.reject(err);`. An even better way would be to not return the caught promise at all, and simply return the original promise. 

---
I believe the same `throw` code is being used in Vuex 4.x however I haven't tested that build to confirm.

Please note that this is a developer experience improvement and is NOT a bug in production environments. I've confirmed this issue in Firefox Developer Edition.

A real-world example: I have an app where I have used Vuex actions to load resources from an API and cache them in the Vuex store. These API requests are promise-based (fetch) and this promise is returned by the action in order for the calling code to await the request. In some situations the API request will fail and reject the promise *without throwing an error*, which is then caught and handled properly. However despite my code being resilient, my devtools debugger will always pause because Vuex is deliberately throwing an error.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Vuex4 - typings for store.getters
Issues.Body:
Forgive me if I'm missing something but it seems that for Vuex4 there is no way to provide typings for our getters, only state. As a result `store.getters` is of type `any` which is not ideal for typescript users.

Is this an intentional design decision?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Vuex4 - typings for store.getters" (#1956)

Issues.Title: Do mutations on next tick
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
When modifying data in the stores I want the action callback to be called before every mutation.
E.g: I'm in a modal and I delete the currently viewed object, I want to call my router.push before the object is effectively deleted.

### What does the proposed API look like?
The new API would not change (in appearance) : all the commits would be applied in a batch after the action is terminated.
The only breaking change would be that we cannot trust the state after the commit but it's not a problem if you call your mutations with data independent of the state (which is a best practice)

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Do mutations on next tick" (#1955)

Using StoreObject instead of State allows for more

  * the params links to definition on VS Code
* The inside of StoreObject-calls(ex,  commit()) may have
  `any` type
* mapXxx() are not changed.
* Not supported `root`, `namespaced` flags

Issues.Title: Vuex - watch option in definition - WHY?
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Please do not close this without looking through ALL the links below.

People have asked, but as far as I have read and looked through discussion forums, no one has actually given an answer.

You'll notice that discussions just get closed but always without an answer or meaningful discussion,

https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/issues/1951  
I ask "why this isn't part of the Vuex API", and the answer was "look at #1219". Closed.

Great, I'll take a look!  
https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/issues/1219  
@ralphchristianeclipse asked in 2018, the answer was a question, "What's the practical use case". My answer to that would be it would make Vuex significantly more developer-friendly and make a significantly better developer experience. Which is the reason why Vue was created in the first place - to create a approachable/developer-friendly way to build user interfaces. A bunch of people agreed that the feature would be a good thing. Closed.

https://forum.vuejs.org/t/is-it-possible-to-declare-a-watcher-inside-a-vuex-store/50375  
@mikepatton75 asks if it's possible. The answer is no. Then a bunch of talk about his use-case which didn't need to happen if Vuex just had a watch option, right? Either way, there is no discussion as to WHY the feature isn't available in the Vuex API. So, that's a dead-end as well.

https://forum.vuejs.org/t/vuex-can-i-use-watch-feature-inside-a-vuex-module/75633  
@lwxbr says he does an "extensive workaround" to make a watcher in a store for his use-case, then opens an issue.  But, all he needed was a just simple watcher, right?

https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/issues/1624  
@lwxbr opens the issue. Closed with reference back to #1219 that didn't have an answer.

https://forum.vuejs.org/t/can-a-vuex-module-register-a-watcher-to-watch-its-local-state/8003  
@jri asks if a store can watch its own state, but with an obscurely worded question about a circular file import that is pretty easy to fix with using a 3rd file. But, it never got answered, probably because the question was too obscure? But, perhaps the reason why it was obscure was probably because @jri just needed a simple watcher, but didn't have it, so it was hard to explain the problem in the first place.


### What does the proposed API look like?
Plenty of people have already done this and have been ignored. So, that has proven to be unproductive. I'm simply asking a question "why" and am requesting an answer and/or productive discussion about it so that developers who have the same thought in the future have a productive place to look and understand why Vuex doesn't have a watch option.

Ideally, I'd like to hear from a creator of Vuex with in-depth knowledge about Vuex/Vue as well as the philosophies behind them.

Please do not give just a random answer like, "it's not necessary" because, don't forget, Vue "isn't necessary" either. Let's all use Vanilla! 

I myself am a creator of a UI framework that I designed for beginner developers to learn JavaScript while also making UI frameworks easier to learn later on down the road. I've even taught Vue+Vuex to an entire development team at a company. So, I know how important the core philosophy of a library is.

I have utmost respect for the developers of Vue and Vuex for making such incredible libraries, and I would hope to have that respect reciprocated with an actual productive discussion into this core feature.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
